profileText: A Representative from Ohio; born in Newfane, Windham County, Vt., March 17, 1818; moved to Salem, N.Y., and in 1830 to Guilford, Medina County, Ohio; attended the public schools; studied medicine at Seville for one year; moved to Medina in 1836 and engaged in mercantile pursuits; also studied law; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Medina; member of the State house of representatives in 1846 and 1847; member of the State senate in 1848 and 1849, serving as its president; elected as a Republican to the Thirty-sixth Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Cyrus Spink; reelected to the Thirty-seventh Congress and served from October 11, 1859, to March 3, 1863; was not a candidate for renomination in 1862 to the Thirty-eighth Congress; entered the Union Army in 1864 as colonel of the One Hundred and Sixty-sixth Regiment; declined the appointment of Governor of Idaho Territory; resumed the practice of law; also interested in banking and mercantile pursuits; delegate to the Loyalist Convention at Philadelphia in 1866; died in Medina, Medina County, Ohio, April 16, 1876; interment in Spring Grove Cemetery.

note.content: Elected to fill vacancy caused by the death of Cyrus Spink, and took his seat December 5, 1859.

researchRecord.name: In the Ralph Waldo Emerson Papers, 1876, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Ralph Waldo Emerson to Harrison Blake written on December 20, 1876. In the letter, Ralph Emerson notifies Harrison Blake that he is sending two trunks containing manuscripts of Henry David Thoreau.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: In Henry David Thoreau Papers, 1853, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A six page letter from Henry David Thoreau from the text in the "Familiar Letters of Thoreau," dating from April 10, 1853.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1884, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Harrison Blake to Charles Aldrich written on November 20, 1884, concerning the letters from Henry David Thoreau.

researchRecord.name: ca. 1881, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: An inscription and autograph written in a copy of Thoreau's "Early Spring In Massachusetts" edited by Harrison Blake. The notes written in pencil appear to have been made in preparation for a new edition.
